Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Ketamine and Nefopam for Potentiating Opioid Analgesia

Participants.evidence: Conducted at [Study Setting], this randomised controlled trial included adults eligible for opioid analgesia.

Intervention.evidence: 100 to receive ketamine 10 mg and 100 to receive nefopam 20 mg.

Objective.evidence: The objective of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of ketamine and nefopam in enhancing opioid analgesia.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the reduction in opioid requirement over a 24-hour period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for patients and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to receive ketamine 10 mg and 100 to receive nefopam 20 mg.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Both ketamine and nefopam reduced opioid requirements by approximately 40% (mean difference = [value], 95% CI [range]; p = [value]).

Harms.evidence: In the ketamine group, sedation was reported, while the nefopam group experienced tachycardia and sweating.
